title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.10.8 | 30-05-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: ओम अज्ञान तिमिरान्धस्य ज्ञानान्जनिषलाकया चक्षरुन्मीलितं येनातस्मै श्री गुरवे नमः
नमा ओम विष्णु पादाया कृष्ण प्रेष्ठाय भूतले श्रीमते भक्ति वेदान्त स्वामिन्नितिनामिने
नमस्ते सारस्वते देवे गौरवाणी प्रचारिने निर्विशेशा शून्यवादी पाश्चात्यदेशतारिने जय श्री कृष्ण चैतन्या प्रभू नित्यानंदा श्री अद्वैत गदाधरा श्री वासादी गौरभक्त वृन्दा
हरे कृष्णा हरे कृष्णा कृष्ण कृष्णा हरे हरे हरे राम हरे रामा राम रामा हरे हरे
ओम नमो भगवते वासु देवाया नारायणम नमस्कृत्य नरम्चैवनरोत्तमं देवीम सरस्वतीम व्यासं ततो जयमुदीरयेत
In this session we will be discussing from the 8th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
आमंत्र्यचाभ्यनु ज्ञातः परिश्वज्याभिवाध्यतं आरुरोह रथम् कैश्चित् परिश्वक्तो अभिवाधितः
The meaning of this verse is, afterwards, when the Lord asked permission to depart and the king gave it,
the Lord offered his respects to Maharaj Yudhishtira by bowing down at his feet.
And the king embraced him.
After this, the Lord, being embraced by others and receiving their obeisances, got into his chariot.
So this was described as the title of the chapter, Departure of Lord Krishna for Dwaraka from Hastinapura.
So Krishna, after finishing his work of conducting the battle of Kurukshetra,
and installing Maharaj Yudhishtira as the emperor of the world,
he was now leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka.
Now the description here is that Krishna, even though he is the supreme personality of Godhead,
he conducts himself in an ideal manner, setting an example for everyone else,
that how the...
...younger ones should show respect to the elders.
Krishna is, that is explained by Prabhupada in the purport,
Maharaj Yudhishtira was the elder cousin of Lord Krishna.
So Maharaj Yudhishtira is elder to Krishna.
And therefore, while departing from him,
the Lord bowed down at the king's feet.
King refers to Yudhishtira.
So Krishna is bowing down to Yudhishtira's feet.
This is the etiquette, this is the culture.
Krishna is younger to Yudhishtira, so therefore he is bowing down.
And Yudhishtira, what is Yudhishtira doing?
The king, that is Yudhishtira, embraced him as a younger brother.
Yudhishtira embraced him.
Although,
the king knew perfectly well
that Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead.
Yudhishtira knows.
At the time of Krishna's advent in this world,
5,000 years back,
very few people knew Krishna to be the supreme personality of Godhead.
Most of them could not recognize him.
So,
this is another reason why people cannot recognize that Krishna behaves
as if he is one among all of us.
But then Krishna also performs activities which are extraordinary,
which establish his position as the supreme lord.
When Krishna is playing with the cowherd boys,
it looks like he is one among them.
But when there is a war,
there is a war.
There is a war.
There is a war.
There is a danger.
Some demon comes to attack.
Krishna effortlessly kills the demons and dispatches them.
So,
that killing the demons is not at all an ordinary activity.
It's not possible for anyone else to do that.
Or lifting the Govardhan hill,
that's not possible for anyone to do.
Even though he is just a seven-year-old boy,
he lifted the Govardhan hill,
he lifted the Govardhan hill on his little left finger.
So, certain activities of Krishna are extraordinary.
But if somebody hears about it,
they don't have the proper understanding about who is Krishna.
They tend to disbelieve it,
or they tend to think it is some kind of mythological story.
But actually, Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead.
He has unlimited power.
So, it is not at all impossible for Krishna to lift the Govardhan hill,
or to kill some big demons.
But,
Krishna also performs activities as if he is an ordinary person.
So, here it is being described how the exchange took place
when he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka.
When he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka,
the Lord took pleasure when some of his devotees
accepted him as less important in terms of love.
No one is greater than or equal to the Lord,
but he takes pleasure in being treated as younger than his devotees.
See, this is Krishna's transcendental pastime,
that even though those who recognize him,
they respect him as the supreme Lord,
they offer obeisances always, under all circumstances.
Everyone offers obeisances to him as the supreme Lord.
But, Krishna takes pleasure when his pure devotees
treat him as an equal or treat him as a subordinate.
Krishna takes pleasure.
So, that is the personal aspect of
the Lord.
The Lord is the supreme Lord,
as a personality.
This is the feature of a personality.
That they take pleasure or they love something,
then it doesn't matter whether etiquette demands something else.
So, these are all transcendental pastimes of the Lord,
and the impersonalist cannot enter into the supernatural role,
played by the devotee of the Lord.
The impersonalist, the understanding is absolute truth,
is some impersonal Brahman.
They don't have understanding of the personality of Godhead,
beyond the impersonal Brahman understanding.
Bhagavad Gita explains,
brahmano hi pratishtaham.
Krishna is the source of the impersonal Brahman,
but the impersonalists do not know this.
Therefore, they cannot appreciate these pastimes of Krishna.
These pastimes of Krishna and his pure devotees.
Now, as regards Bhima and Arjuna,
because they were equal in age to Lord Krishna,
they embraced him.
So, mutually they embraced each other,
because they are equals.
And, Nakula and Sahadeva are younger to Krishna,
therefore they bowed down to Krishna.
So, this is the description of Krishna
living for Dwaraka.
He mounted his chariot,
and after he was properly bowing down,
and receiving embraces, etc.
The 9th and 10th verse describe further,
Subhadra Draupadi Kunti Virata Tanaya Tatha
Gandhari Dhritarashtrascha
Yuyatsur Gautamo Yamao
Vrukodascha Dhaumyascha
Striyo Matsya Sudadayaha
Nasehire Vimukhyanto Viraham
Sarangadhanmanaha
This is two verses,
the 9th and the 10th verses.
In these verses,
it is described,
the translation of these two verses.
At that time,
Subhadra Draupadi Kunti Uttara
Gandhari Dhritarashtra
Yuyatsur Krupacharya Nakula
Sahadeva Bhimasena Dhaumya
and Satyavati,
all nearby,
all nearly fainted,
because it was impossible for them
to bear separation from Lord Krishna.
So this is describing,
what is the reaction
of the residents of the palace of Hastinapura
when Krishna was leaving for Dwarka.
Krishna has mounted his chariot.
Now what was the reaction?
They all felt
that this separation
is impossible to bear for them.
All these personalities.
So Prabhupada explains in the purport
the reason for this.
Prabhupada says,
Lord Sri Krishna is so attractive
for the living beings,
especially for the devotees,
that it is impossible for them
to tolerate separation.
This is the meaning of
the word Krishna.
He is supremely attractive.
So he is attractive for everyone.
But then somebody may say,
I don't feel attracted to Krishna.
That is explained by Prabhupada here as
the conditioned soul.
All of us are conditioned souls
in the present condition,
the present situation.
We are all conditioned souls.
Under the spell of the illusory energy,
the illusory energy forgets the Lord.
So because of the influence of illusion
on all of us,
we forget Krishna.
That means we do not recognize Krishna.
We do not remember Krishna.
We do not know about Krishna like that.
Otherwise,
the living entity can never forget Krishna.
If we are not under the influence of illusion,
we cannot,
we can never forget Krishna.
So the feeling of such separation
cannot be described
but can simply be imagined
by devotees only.
What is the kind of separation
a devotee feels?
Another devotee can understand that.
Non-devotees cannot understand.
What is this?
Because this is separation
from the most beloved personality,
the most attractive personality,
the most loving personality,
the most intimately related personality.
So the separation is unbearable.
It's unbearable.
Prabhupada also describes,
not only an example is given here,
Krishna leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka,
but when Krishna left Vrindavan
and came to Mathura,
after it is described here,
after the separation from Vrindavan
of the great innocent rural covered boys,
girls, ladies and others,
they all felt shocked throughout their lives,
the Vrajavasis.
They felt the shock of separation
and they experienced that throughout their lives
because Krishna never went back.
Though when leaving Vrindavan,
Krishna told the Vrajavasis,
I'll come back after few days.
I got some work in Mathura.
But He never returned.
Krishna never returned to Vrindavan.
So the Brajavasis, rest of their life they simply were crying and crying and crying and crying in separation from Krishna. This is their attachment to Krishna.
So that is described here. The separation of Radharani, the most beloved, covered girl, is beyond expression of all the devotees. The topmost devotee is Radharani. She felt the separation the most.
So then it is also described once later on, much later. They met at Kurukshetra during a solar eclipse, the Brajavasis and?
Krishna coming from Dwaraka to Kurukshetra. Brajavasis coming from Vrindavan to Kurukshetra. And the feeling which was expressed by them is heart-rending.
The feeling the Brajavasis expressed on seeing Krishna in Kurukshetra at the time of solar eclipse, that is very, very, very touching.
There is of course a difference in the qualities of the transcendental devotees of the Lord. Not all are identical that way.
They have varieties of relationships. But none of them who has ever contacted the Lord by direct communion or otherwise can leave him for a moment.

That is never possible. Separation is never possible. And if at all they are separated, they feel that within the core of their heart, I cannot tolerate being away from Krishna even for a single moment. A fraction of a second I cannot tolerate.
So deep and so intimate is the attachment for Krishna among pure devotees. So this we have to understand.
I will stop here. Thank you very much. Hare Krishna.
Going back to the flame of our days fools.
To Arunachala.
And more often than not.
Indinga held very dear to his heart the desire of the Lord, for it is eternal.
And lay in the horse audio on camel bull.

In daytime.

neglectful about other people indifferent to other people no he's always equal to everybody
but his devotees he has got some special affection so I'll stop here thank you very much Hare Krishna
